prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) emission around MRC0156-252
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging of CO(3-2) emission across the halo environment MRC 0156-252 (z=2.016) at an observing frequency of 114.7 GHz. Our main goal is to image the very widespread CO(3-2) emission across distances of several 100 kpc. To reach this goal we need the most compact ALMA array configuration, combined with ACA data of the 7m array, resulting in a synthesised beam of 3 - 5 arcsec (depending on weighting/tapering).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require a standard spectral-line setup with four 2 GHz basebands. This gives us ~5000 km/s velocity coverage per baseband, enough to cover the signal of FWZI~1000-2000 km/s and leave enough line-free channels for accurate continuum subtraction. We will perform a spectral averaging at the telescope to obtain a raw velocity resolution of ~10 km/s, which we will further bin off-line during the data reduction. One of the basebands has to be centred on the redshifted CO. Drouart et al (2014) show from a far-infrared spectral energy distribution fitting that we may be able to detect the continuum as well. We therefore place the remaining three basebands to cover the continuum, also because no other interesting lines can be targeted properly within the LO settings.

We propose to obtain the coarsest spatial resolution with the 12m array, or ~3 arcsec. The reason is that we are targeting the lowest surface brightness emission of CO. One cannot merely smooth radio data to maximize sensitivity for low surface brightness emission. An interferometer maps the emission through a discrete sampling of signals on various baselines. The baseline-length determines the largest angular scale of emission to which that baseline is sensitive -- any emission more extended than this will be impossible to detect on that baseline, increasing only the noise in the data. To be most sensitive to the weak signals of very widespread molecular gas, it is thus essential that ALL baselines are as short as possible. We have extensive hands-on experience in this matter (see Emonts et al 2014, 2015).
**In the OT, the 12m time request is automatically assigned under "extended" configuration, but the ALMA helpdesk clarified that the actual observations will happen in the compact configuration**
We do not know the exact extent of the molecular gas we will be detecting, or what are its kinematics. However, it is known that the largest giant Lya halos cover over 250 kpc in diameter (i.e. 30 arcsec at z~2), and that cool neutral gas and dust also have been observed on similar scales. Our 3 arcsec beam (corresponding to ~25 kpc at z~2) is therefore sufficient to image potential widespread CO emission (in fact, we will probably enhance our sensitivity by decreasing the resolution even further through adding the ACA and possibly tapering the data to the ~5 arcsec ATCA beam of CO(1-0)). Moreover, the warm gas in these giant Lya halos is often very quiescent, which means that it may thus not show significant kinematical changes across the full 250 kpc environment. This means that we require the ACA to make sure we are sensitive to this very widespread molecular emission. Adding the ACA can potentially be rewarding, as no experiment has been done before that truly targeted the most extended quiescent gas reservoirs that we are after. Therefore, we are exploring uncharted terrain with a potential for fundamental new high-z discoveries using the ACA.

Our technical requirements are set by our goal that we want to be able to image widespread emission of CO across an extent of at least 250 kpc or 30 arcsec (i.e. the size of the largest know Lya halos) under the assumption that the gas has quiescent kinematics and may thus not show significant kinematical changes across the full 250 kpc environment. In other words, we account for the possibility that the largest angular scale (LAS) of CO features per frequency element is *not* being reduced by gas kinematics, as is the case e.g. in rotating structures. For this we need: 1). observations in the most compact 12m array configuration, to maximize our sensitivity for widespread, low surface brightness emission. We stress that it is crucial to have ALL baselines as short as possible, as we carefully explained in Sect 2.1 of the Science Case; 2). additional observations with the ACA, to be able to recover all the flux on 30 arcsec scales; 3). observations of the lowest possible CO transitions in Band 3, because the lowest CO transitions are the most robust tracers of widespread emission, and because the lowest frequencies give us the smallest uv-range (in kilo-lambda), which again aids in maximizing our sensitivity for very widespread emission.
For MRC 0156-252 at z=2.016, this results in targeting the CO(3-2) line at an observed frequency of 114.7 GHz. The coarsest beam-size that we can get with the most compact ALMA 12m array is ~3 arcsec, but we will take into account that we will add the ACA data and if necessary taper the final data set to the ~5 arcsec resolution of our existing ATCA CO(1-0) data. We will use a standard spectral-line setup in dual polarization, covering 2GHz (~5000 km/s) per baseband. All calculations are based on the 12m array only.
Our sensitivity calculations depend on the expected I_CO(3-2)/I_CO(1-0) intensity ratio. This is unknown for these types of IGM environments, but so far from the central galaxy it is safe to assume that the gas will be significantly sub-thermally excited. Within most high-z starforming and submm galaxies I_CO(3-2)/__CO(1-0) ~ 6 (e.g. Weiss+ 2007, Harris+ 2010, Ivison+ 2011), which is already significantly lower than the I_CO(3-2)/__CO(1-0) ~ 9 of fully thermalised gas often encountered in quasars (e.g. Riechers+ 2011). However, given that we are exploring gas reservoir far outside the galaxy, we will assume an even more conservative I_CO(3-2)/__CO(1-0) ~ 3 to calculate our lower limits on integration time, which is consistent with the value for quiescent gas predicted by Ivison+ (2011).
Assuming I_CO(3-2)/I_CO(1-0) ~ 3, our goal is to detect the integrated weak 5 sigma CO(1-0) signal at a firm 10 sigma level in CO(3-2) assuming a similar beam-size (note that if the gas shows a more typical I_CO(3-2)/I_CO(1-0) ~ 6, this would increase to an integrated 20 sigma level, or even a bit higher when including the ACA data). It should give us the sensitivity to also trace the CO(3-2) at places where CO(1-0) was not detected, or resolve it kinematically. All values for the CO(1-0) emission have been published in Emonts et al 2014 (their Table 2). For MRC 0156-252, the integrated CO(1-0) signal has I_CO(1-0) = 0.38 Jy/beam x km/s across FWZI = 2000 km/s. This means that we expect the CO(3-2) signal to peak at I_CO(3-2) ~ 3 x 0.38 = 1.14 Jy/beam x km/s. To detect this at 10 sigma across 2000 km/s, we thus need to reach a noise level of (1140/10)/2000 = 0.057 mJy/beam per 2000 km/s resolution element at 114.7 GHz. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this requires 1.39h on-source, or 2.03h in total (including calibration/overheads) using 35 12m antennas. Our project can use the poorest useful weather conditions at Chajnantor.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Giant Ly-alpha halos of warm gas have long been known to surround powerful high-z radio galaxies. We recently discovered large reservoirs of cold molecular CO(1-0) gas located beyond the radio lobes in the 100+ kpc-scale environment of three massive radio galaxies at z~2. These CO reservoirs are as luminous as those found in submm galaxies, but they lack any far-infrared counterpart in deep Spitzer imaging. These results suggest that large amounts of widespread and possibly diffuse molecular IGM may be spread throughout the halo environments of massive high-z galaxies. If so, it may provide observational evidence for predicted key processes that drive their early evolution, such as cooling flows, cold accretion, or jet-triggered star-formation. We propose to target our three CO-rich sources with ALMA to trace the full extent of the molecular IGM on >100 kpc scales and investigate its nature. We will use ALMA and ACA in their most compact configurations to maximize our sensitivity for detecting low surface brightness CO emission. This novel use of ALMA may ultimately give us new insights into the gas physics in the halo environments outside massive galaxies in the Early Universe.
